div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: QUESTION AND ANSWER.
div.p: The letter on "Anglo-German Relations" which appeared in the "Times," yesterday week over the signature of a number of eminent German Professors and other persons of intellectual distinction in Germany, is not exactly "felix opportunitate." The question which these German Professors ask briefly is: -
Why does your Press bate ob ko ľ" Ther complaint is against thestatementa "attributing to Germany sinister designs against Boglaod," which, they say, are pat forward

with increasing frequency" in English journals. Let us admit at once, freely and fally, that the fact is so ; furthermore, that we ourselves are among the offenders, and that | the "Times' ' is just as bad. What, then, have these distinguished Germans to say by way of refutation of the charge of hostility to our country, which is, we admit, frequently drought against the German Government, the Government of the Prassianised German Empire 1 Well, to begin with, they tell 08 that they themselves, "though living in widely distant parts of Germany and moving in different spheres of German society and party life," have never heard an attack on England seriously discussed or approved by any man or section of the German public worth noticing.`` Then they treat is to the agual common-form disclaimer of any aggressive intentions on the part of the German Navy, and the stock references to Shakespeare, Goethe, and the debt of gratitude, literary, scientific, artistio, and philosophical, which each of the two countries owes to the other. "Wby, then, does your Press hate as 80? Ara not these facts sufficient to prove the entire good faith of Germany and the after absence of any intention to make a wanton attack | apon Eaglani !" We will endeavour to show why we do not feel justified in saying our mea culpa opon that invitation.

To begin with, there is an ambiguity latent in the word "Germany." The old Germany, politically and socially disonited, and intellectually idealist rather than fiercely materialist, exista no longer. It has been replaced by the Prassianised Germany of to-day, which is the expansion of the Process of Frederick the | Great and of Bismarck. That a majority of the German people want war with Eogland, or with any other country, we do not believe. But when German Professors tell us that they have never met an anti-English German worth noticing, we are bound to reply that it is precisely by other German Professors that the anti-Baglish agitation of the past few years has been most actively carried on. Are those learned gentlemen atterley anI worthy of notice ? Even; however, if we admitted that their influence upon the German people has been infinitesimally small—which we do not in the least concede-there would remain the question of the setpolioy of the German Government. That policy has long been open to the gravest suspicion, and in no department of public affairs more than in naval matters. The Preamble to the German Navy Bill of 1900 says "Germany must have a fleet or sach strength that a war against the mightiest Power would involve risks threatening the supremacy of that Power." Daring the Boer war Germany would anquestionably huyo | attacked as if she had darei; bat she was,

in the Kaiser's own words, "in bitter peed of Ta strong pavy," and so she dared not attempt to promote "the German interest in the Trang vaal as an independent State," or (we quote the Kaiser again) attempt at that janotare to enable the German Empire "to reach a place which it has not yet attained." If, however, there is any man, British of foreign, who seriously believes, at this time of day, that the German fleet would not try conolasions with ours at the first favourable opportunity, if it had a reasonable hope of victory, we shall certainly not waste time in trying to convert him. As to Goetho, Shakespeare, and the magical gla8808, we will only say that it is perhaps more profitable to forget them for the moment, and to look at what is going on | around as just now. For months past Barope has been on tenderbooks owing to German policy. An International Conference, which nobody but Germany wants, is about to mest, at the instance of Germany, to decide how far the interests and the arrangements of France and England are to be interfered with to suit Gorman purposes. At such a time wo, at all events, shall not try to sow suspicion in the minds of the French by declaring, with Lord Avebury, that "for us, as between Bngland and Germany, there is no frontier to be defended." We earnestly desire peace with Germany; but we will not bind a bandage round our own eyes and pretend that tho san is not shining at noon-day. Germany talks ever of poaca bat she rattles the sword 80 loudly in the gabbard that her voice is drowned. Let the Government of Berlin frankly set the example of a policy of peace, and it will find the Boglish Press and publio only too thankful to be able to second its honest endeavours.

div.head: El Rafei's Works
div.p: Sheikh Mobomed Rashid el-Rafei, son of the late Grand Mufti, Sheikh Abd el Kader El Rafei, is undertaken to publish the works of his father, and has begun by printing a large work on Mouler law entitled "El abrir el Mukhtar." This book, which is DOW about to leave the printer's hands, is said to be the best treatise on the Hanefi law.

div.head: ON THE NILE.
div.p: H.R.H. Princess Lopise, Duchess of Argyll. and the Duke of Ar yil left Cairo at midday Co-day for their trip up the river, which is expected to be lost ab: ut 8 month. They have Chartered the daba beub Nisgata from the Anglo-American Company, and though it is not one of the largest boats, no more convenient one could be found for their purpose. The bout has been redecorated for this trip, and the Balloon, which is amida ibps, is delight:fal with cool colourings of green, white and heliotrope. Leading off the ssloon is the small drawingroom, gay with Oriental bupgings and cosily cushioned chairs. A small companion lead Irom the drawing-room to the upper deck, with its rogs and wicker chairs and brightly colourad awnings. The chief cabina are amidships and these have windows on either side and are as spotless as white paint and dainty hangings 240 make them. The cabin for the guests are farther aft, and there is another cosy lounge at the stern of the boat where meals will be loved, and where many a delightful hour of dolce far niente will be passed. The services of ihe best chèt in Egypt have been secured, and everything has been done to make this trip a record of comfort.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: "L1 FAVORITA.".

Faraday's performance was disappointing, and only the baritone, Sig. Amato, stave off liraster. He acted, sing and declaimed right well as Alfonso XI. His phrasing and his taste were similarly admirable, and confirmed the favourable impression his audience had formad of his abilities. Signora Lavin h33 an excellent mezzo-soprano voice which she used with an alarming prodigality. The aria, "O mio Perbando" in the third act was her swan-song; it was capitalistically sung but she had nothing further to give one: probably the muric did not fruit when her display in Aida was admirable. Per pand's voice was fresh and pleasant but barely powerful enough and the rest were not in the least remarkable. The corps de ballet met with a good reception and Sig. Z ccani did his beat with an orchestra degraded by Donizett to the level of a guitar band.

The barrel organ and the monkey are also seen at Port Said. div.head:
ALEXANDRIA DOCTORS' FEES.
CONFERENCE.
div.p: SATISEUT SETTLEMENT PENDING

Dr. Schloss Bay, as Chairman of the Alexandria Medical Association, has replied to the president of the international d-legates selected by the committee at the recent meeting in regard to the new medical tariff, fixing the time and place of a conference at 5.30 p.m. on Monday next at the headquarters of the Alexandria Medical Association,

It is believed that the negotiations at sibiu cu fine will lead to a satisfactory settlement of ihe question. The delegatus are prepared to tmat with the Medical Association on fair and equitable terms in the interests of all the inhabitants of Alexandrit. The fact that Dr. Schiego Bay has shown that he is willing to meet the delegates and diagg3 the questions at issue with them is a siga that the crisis is over.

There is of course on these occasions a good deal of diplomacy, but it is the minor diplomacy in which traits are adjusted, not the major diplomacy in which vital issues are decided. The delegates are fully prepared to meet the membril the Alexandria Medical A 4600IAtion in C try spirit, and the courteous reply of Dr. Schiess Bey leads them to the belief that a satisfactory arrangement will be arriy.dat.

After the conference the delegates will convene another public meeting under the aegis of the Risorgimento Society, to eat before those from whom they had received their mandate the results of the conference.

div.head: IMPORTANT LAND DEAL.
div.p: A very important purchase of agricultural land has been made by the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company, Limited. The land is situated in the neighbourhood of D-m-boor and is 1,690 fadd-os in extent. The purchase price was £1,000. It belonged to the Tabet brothers.

div.head: BRITISH INTERESTS IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Leigh Wool, C.M G., & member of the influential London firm of stockbrokers, Messrs. Basil, Montgom ry, FitzGerald and Co., has been making a short stay in this country. He is now at the Savoy Hotel, on his return from a trip up the Nile.Unfortunately he is compelled to return to London earlier than he anticipated owing to an attack of dysentery. During his stay here, Mr. Leigh Wood has been much impressed by the great prosperity of the country and considers it especially interesting as a fio d for English investors.

All will be glad to see a firm of such high standing interested in Egyptian enterprises. Everything which tends to increase the number of such London buses doing business here must help to broaden the field for bona fide investors and to bring the two markets more in sympathy with one another.

div.head: SALT AND SODA CO'S DIVIDEND. To me EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Dear Sir,--A pozice appeared in the Gazette" that a dividend of 4 % was payable to the shareholders of this concern on and after the 1st January current.

I am & registered shareholder. Under the late "maragemont Hooker" I always received my dividend warrants with utmost popoto. iry, but it appears that a change for the worse his feet in. After having waited a fortnight I wrote to the Direction in Cairo and gut replied to the effect tias the dividend warrants had been posted from Loudon on 9 h inst. to the National Bank, Caro. This is now th. 19.b Jquery and no news of my warrant.

Surely it was the business of the Direction to notify those interested of this extraordinary postponement of payment of dividend warrant, and it would also be interesting to know the reason for it all.-I am, etc.,
J.A. Alexandria, 19 h January.

div.head:
EGYPTO-AMERICAN TRADE.
BIG INCREASE.
div.p: THE AWAKENING OF THE YANKEE.*

One of the most significant items of the returns of the Customs Administration for the past year has been the increase in the Ame. rican imports to Egypt. In 1904 America's total imports only amounted to LB. 284,227 in valor, but last year this was greatly increased, the value being L.E. 487,685, more than double the figures for 1903, i.e.,

L.B. 238.988. | The great bulk of the exporta come from the Unitary States and their kresge is done in a great asgre to the lower freight rates and the decrease in the> time occupied in transit. 'The most favoured route from America to Egypt is now-a-days by way of Naples hy the White Star Line and North German Lloyd's steam grg. The record from Now, York to Alexandria for merchandise is sixtoon days.

Besides the circumstances of cheaper freights and knicker transit, Yankee manufacturers are becoming alive to the advantages of having & sharing in the Egyptian market. Amer. icans, however, are considerably handicapped by their hard and fast rules ay to the giving of credit. In this respect they have a great deal of lee-way to make op in order to compete on equal terms with European mer. chanta trading in Egypt and the Levant. 1 We have noticed that of late the taste for American specialities, such for example as office furniture, refrigerators, chair, etc., has been on the top-grade in Egypt, and there is no reason why the American import trade in the Valley of :he Nile should no: be capable of considerable further extension. In the opinion of many Americans interested in Egypt, their trade hears from the lack of & Chamber of Commerce at Alexandria. Considering the growth of America's commercial interests here it is a wan! which most decidedly ought to be remedied.

Among the successful American import com. Panies in Egypt are the American Manufacturers' Agency, the New York Export and Import Company, and the Hamauker Delius & Co. The latter two companies are represented here by German commission hoone*, ! bat the first-named is established in Alex. andria and deals directly with the American manufacturer.

div.head: GEORGE S. P. C. A..
div.p: Sobag, Priday. A Khedivial decree being promulgated for the establi-hment of a branch of the 8.P C.:.: G! ir ch Mondirieh, a meeting of the notables of the province was to day convened at the Moudirieh at Sobag. Some 60 people attended, comprising the wealthiest add best known pop in the province.

The Mordir, Ibrahim Boy Nabeeb, opered the proceedings with a few well-chosen words, pointing out the necessity for the establishment. ment of such a branch and appealing to the Audience for fans. These were immediately forthcoming, nearly L E. 300 being subscribed in & fw minute,' *bile many premier of further sms. We made. After a short discussion, we decided to erect a stable with accommodation for 20 animals at Ghirga.
Mr. Hartshore, thy honorary secretary, thanked the audience for the quick and generals 're-pon-e malo to the appeal for funds and increl a vote of thanks to the Moudir, which was unanimously carried.

Abdalla Bey Wahabi, Director of Irrigation, emphasized the urgent need there was for a branch in Ghirga Mondrian and tendered his thanks, and the thanks of those present, tı Mr. Hart-hori e for having inaugurated one.
The proceedings thon terminated.

Among those present were the Mondir, the Sub-Moodie, ibo Mamour of Ghirgeh, Abdalla Bey Wababi, Mr. Macnagbten, of the Int-rior, Mr. Smell, of the National Bank, Mr. HartShorne, of the Agricultural Bank, Mustapha Bey Abin Wahab, Amin: Bry el' Arif, Rishwan By Hammarly, Abel Mog's Bey el Ansary, Yogi B y el Arif, Hanafi Pey Forell, Mab. vond By Shania Wily, Mobamed Bey Tamem, Rowan Buy Atis, Mohammed Bey Kharoun, Mohamed Bey Amin Abon Stet, Ahmed Bey Hamam, Abbau Bey Kbaroon el Miengabuli, Hawrgi Abdel Malak, Magar and many others.

div.head:
GREAT PYRAMID.
SOUTH AIR CHANNEL OPENED.
div.p: MR. COVINGTON'S EXCAVATIONS.

| At 12.30 p.m. yesterday Mr. Covington, after a fortnight's very bard work, ancceeded in opening the south air channel of the King's chamber in the Great Pyramid. The channel, which was opened in 1837 by Colonel (afterwards General) Howard-Vyeo, who won. fortunately made no arrangements for keeping it permanently open, was choked by debris carried by the rain wash down the south face of the Pyramid. In February, 1902, Mi. Covington, by clearing the great entrance passage at Ali Maiman's recoge, and by removing all the debris from the well-shaft, reduced the internal temperature of the Pyramid from 89 to 27 degrees Fahrenheit. The opening of that p2888ges, in conjunction with the opening of the south air channel above referred to, will, it is hoped, further reduce the internal temperature of the Pyramid to what Professor Piszzi-8wyth believes to have been its original temperature of 69 degrees.

This King's chamber S. air-channel extends. ing from the chameter to the hundred and fourth course of the S. face of the pyramid some 330 feet above the ground, was originally 174 feet in length, with a slope of 45 degrees with a five-foot horizontal entrance to the King's Chamber and about 9 inches square. It's length was reduced to, roughly, 160 fast by the removal of the casing stone of the pyramid in Saracen times.

The obstruction which proved extremely difficult to remove owing to the rain wruh having somewhat solidified the mixture of sand and limestone of which it was composed, extended for 61 feet of the passage, commencing atoat 25 feet from the King's chamber. It could only be removed by working from the chamber, and Mr. Covington employed a boring rod, kindly lent by Major Tacker, RE, I made of malacos , with a steal woim sorrow attached which cat into the chatraction, loosening it and releasing it, after which a spiral brush was used to withdraw the released débris from the air channel. The stones imbedd:d in the débris, though not domoroas, were very troublesome and necessitated very ski!for manipulation of the boring rod to dislodge them. The largest stone, which in a Bongo supported the débris, was eight inches in length, six by breadth, and three in thickDe38, and how it got so far down the channel is a mystery. The passage is now opened throughout, the Darroweat part being about 3 or 4 inches in diameter, and the drought even though this small. Aperture is enough to draw in a suspended handkerchief.

When the channel is abc lately clear for the full 9 ios:9, there can be little doubt that the purification of the air in the interior will be complete. Tourists will no longer have to complain of foal air and odour of bats and mustiness, and visits to the wonderful interior of the Pyramid will be made with far more comfort than was over the case in the past. La ley visitors, who have been known to faint before now in the stifling chamher, will be able to admire the saperb masonry and study the remarkable internal features of the great stature. They would feel especially grateful to Mr. Covington and the Antiquities Ser: vice, who gave the necessary concession for the Clearing. There is no fear of the channel being again obstructed as the concession especially provides for the placing of a steel funnel, invisible from the exterior, at the exterior end of the chancel; 80 placed that, while allowing freo passage of the air, it will prevent the passage from again being choked by sand and débris.

Mr. Covington is now searching for the undiscovered exterior ends of the Qcoon's chamber air channels, the inner extremities of which were discovered by Weyman Dickson in 187%. Both channels are c'esr for 352 feet, the length of the boring rods inserted, and may contaia do obstruction as far as the exterior of the pyramid.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE.
div.p: Thursday's small dance was an enormous success. It surpassed even the best dances of last year, which proves that Ghezireh Palace, with its fino ball and ballroom, is and always will be the place in Cairo for fasbiopable dances and balls. For dinner, the dining room and restaurant were crowded. Amongst the guests dining there we will mention a few. Mr. Whittskor Jones had a party of 16, including Mr. and Mrs. Idding, Sir John and Lady R, gers, Mme. Aghion, Capt. Storey, Miss Cambalage, Mrs. and Miss Bror yate, Mlle. de Brémont, Mr. Forestier Walker, Princesse Lucienne Marat, Major Good, Mr. W. Fraser. Mr. Douglas Vickers entertained a party of 6, amongst whom were Col. and Mrs. Markham. Sir Hugh Bailey had Col. Watson and a party of 5. Count and Countess Lmche entertained Judge and Mrs. Niebolm. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Glazi Mukhtar Pasba, the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, paid a visit yesterday to Sheikh Yebia, the Grand Cadi, who is Suffering from a slight attack of malaria.
The Hod. Bvya Boring has had a slight rotation of fever, but his general condition is satisfactory.
Major and Mrs. Wyane entertained a select party for dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, including H.R.A. Prince Charles of Sweden and soito.
At the Duke of Argyll's table at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening we noticed Col. J.B. Watson. The distinguished party after. wards went to the Khedivial Opera House.
Mr. and Mrs. J.P. Gold entertained Col. and Mrs. Patterson Bey to diddor at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday, and Count and Countess Sierstorpff had the Doc de Civella at their table.

Among the well-known people down at the Savoy, is Lord de Clifford. He is a great landowner in Ireland, porse-ring some 13,000 aoree in County Mayo. He is the 25th Baron Clifford and succeeded his father in 1894. The first Baron was killed at the battle of Bannockburn, 1814.

Lady Wise, who is also at the Savoy, is the wife of Sir William Lloyd Wine D.L., J.P., P.R.G.8., who was created a Knight in 1904. Sir Lloyd Wise is one of the greatest patent agents of the present day. He was professionally trained in his father's office and Siebe'. Works and for over thirty-five years has borne an active patent law reformar, in which connection he cooperated with the late Tbomas Webster, tha once noted Queen's Coopsol, and father of Lord Alverstone. He is oro of the founders and original member of the Council of the Institute of Patent Agents and was the first president of the Chartered Institute, a position which he bled for seven years,

He took a leading part in bringing about legal recognition of the profession and was examiner in 1893 andør tho Bagiates of Patent Agents' Rala, md he wu the first County Councillor for the Southend Division of Bwan. Be was the author of the novelty examination scheme embodied in the Patent Act of 1909 and of the compulsory lending provisions in the Canadian Patent Aot of 1903 Por over thirty years he has been a loader-writer in "Bagincerio g." and has written many papers on parenting and allied subjects.

| Sir Alfred Peaso, Liberal Member of Parlier meant for the Cleveland division of Yorkshire, who has been staying at the picturesque Hotel da Nil, and has now gone ap tho Nile, in the second baronet of the name, the barodetop being created in 1889; he andoooded his father in 1973. From 1885 to 1892 ha represented York as junior member, his colleague being the late Sir Frank Lockowood, who boonmo junior member in the latter year to Mr. J.G. Botober. He was appointed Resident Magistrate of the Transvaal in 1908 and is a member of the Coupoil of the Royal Agricultural Society and also of the Royal Commission of Horse Breeding. He is well-known as a broodor of the famous Cleveland baya and is keon bunter, whilst he also goes in for big gamo shooting, having visited Asia Minor, Algorii, Tadirin, the Sahara, Somaliland, and Aynioia of booting expeditions.

The Rt. R:v, DJohn Percival, Bishop of Hereford, who has gone to Sudan, belongo ty a well known Westmoreland family. Who received His early education at Appleby Gram. mar School, from which bo paseo into Queen's College, Oxford, where be gained tho jan or mathematical scholarship and double first mode, and finale. He passed the Master of Arts examination in 1861 and is a follower of his old college. He was ordained in 1860 and appointed on assistant master of Rugby and two young later Headmaster of Clifton College. Io 1871 became Prebendary of Bzeter Cathedral, in 1882 he was appointed Canon of Bristol, six years later President of Trinity College, Oxford, and from 1887 to 1895 he was Headmaster of Rugby, which post was assigned to become Bishop of Hereford. Ho has now left for the Sadan on a visit to his son, Captain Paraina), of the Sudan Camel Corpo..

Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Limited.
It has come to the notice of the Company that retailers of salt are selling to the public at a higher rate than 2 m/m the kilo, the price fixed by the Governor ent.
Very retailer before he is able to take coarse orground kalt from the Company agree tot retail the same to the public at 2 m/m the kilo.

The Company does not wish to interfere with legitimate retail trade, but unless retailers kerp to their engagements, the Company will issue the salt direct from its sunnahs to any person applying for it, at the fixed rate, 2 m/s the kilo.

div.p: THE GENERAL ADMINISTRATION of 1 The Wakfs informs the public that it 5038esses at Alexandris, lands covering an area of about 18 føddang, situated on the bank of the El Farkha Canal, part of which is occupied by small houses belonging to the tenants. Anyone wishing to take part in this adjudication over L E. 22075, should apply at the offices of the Wakfs Delegation at Alexandria on Saturday, January 27, 1905, from 9' a.m. to I p.m., to examine the list of lands and make his bid. div.head: A Light Nourishment for General Use.
Allenburys' DIET
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & The aged.
Allen & Hanburys Ltd., Lombard St. London.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton Dire que la semaine qui vient de finir a été extraordinaire, cela n'est pas le cas ; mais, ce qui est incontestable, c'est qu'elle n'a pas manqué d'intérêt avec ces continuelles variations dans l'allure et la tendance du marché auxquelles nous avons assisté et qui, au fond, n'étaient que la répercussion, plus ou moins marquée, de ce qui passait en Amérique et l'écho des nouvelles assorties qui nous servaient journellement l'Étranger. Bo tous cas, comme débat, elle a rompu la monotonie de ces cons. tations de calme auxquelles on avait fini par s'habituer, car, en dépit de l'indifférence de l'Amérique qui nous était venue avec on on deux points de bebe en tout, c'est la fermeté qui a prédominé dans la matinée de samedi et qui nous a valu pour ce jour-là une avance de 1/8 de tallari sur les cours de la veille.

Cet élan, encouragé par la clôture de New York de samedi, s'est accentué dans la journée de lundi et s'est traduit par une seconde avance de 7/32;et si.malgré la continuation de la baste sur les An américains la marche ascendante de nos prix s'est trouvée arrêtée le lendemain, cela est due aux nombreuses réalisations qui ont été la conséquence toute naturelle da moc. vement des jours précédents. Même en clotaire il y a eu un peu de réaction, mais, grâce à la tenue de New-York qui a encore monté de 14 points, les deux séances de mercredi ont été favorables aux barbiers, les prix ayant fini, après quelques légères flac tatiane, par revenir au maximum officiellement enregistré depuis le commence ment de la semaine.

Par contre, 8003 l'influence de la première et unique reculade de l'Américain durant cette huitaine, qui a été de 14 points, la journée d'hier a été calme, mais le soir la tendo du marché a été meilleure, ce qui a semblé être l'indice de bonnes dispositions pour la suite, si le moindre encouragement devait nous venir da dehors. Au fond, ce n'était là qu'un espoir que nourrissantes hasiera, mais cet espoir s'est réalisé quand même, le dien ton spécial de la ba088e qui existe pour l'Egypte ayant voulu que l'Amérique DODB vint ce matin avec 19 points de haasse ! Cette volte face, aussi agréable qu'inattendu, & ranimé un peu le courage des détenteurs de contrats et leur a permis de pousser le mars jusqu'à 16 9/32 ; toutefois, la clôture finale n'a eu lieu qu'à 16 3/16, et cela à la suite de quelques liquidations de gens qui tenaient à empocher leurs bénéfices.
En somme la cote de ce soir est à 7/16 de tallari au-dessus de celle de vendredi dernier : ane pareille amélioration d'est pas à dédaigner, Burtont si les circonstances venaient à la consolider.

Comme activité, les affaires ont été assez satisfaisantes ; néanmoins, il y a eu de la régu. larité et de l'intermittence, mais l'hésitation montrée, par momente, par les intéressés à la haine, s'explique facilement quand on considère les nouvelles et les appréciations contradictoires que New-York et Liverpool se sont amusés à nous câbler tous ces jours derniers. En effet, à moins d'@tre d'un tempérament extraordinairement froid, et ce n'est généralement pas là la qualité dominato da spéculation, il est difficile de ne pas se laisser impressionner par ce que l'on entend dire. Eo tous cas, et ne fût-ce qu'à titre de curiosité, nous résumons comme sait tout ce qui vous a été rapporté durant cette semaine. Le premier jour on nous sert comme hors d'oeuvre : Manchester est solide et la hausse est certaine, ce à quoi quelques baissiers répondent, "mais le ContiNent et l'Amérique ne vont pas du tout et il ne faut pas se faire trop d'illusions, toute hausse ne pouvant qu'être provisoire !"

Le jour avant, on nous dit : les décisions de la Convention de New Orleans de réduire les encomencements pour la prochaine récolte de 10 % et de retenir le solde in venda de la récolte actuelle pour le prix de 15 cents, influencent le petit découvert et l'entraident à Be racheter; mais à cela on oppose l'opinion de personnes réputées très sérieuses, soutenant que la hausse résultant de ces couvertures est artificielle, quoique susceptible d'être momentanément forcée, et qu'en tout cas, la filature est assez approvisionnée pour pouvoir lutter bien plus longtemps qu'on ne le pense. Voyant un pan de calme, le lendemain quelqueanno de nos bons inforinateurs télégre phient: Marché restreint, rien d'intéressant à signaler. Mais pour ajouter 24 heures après : "Demande insuffisante, réaction certaine" et cela probablement pour contrebalancer les avis d'autres sources disant: "Le coton doit monter par son propre mérite," "La demande de l'exportation est énorme, hausse immanquable." Devant la badjene du jour d'après, on annonce : Découvert fis i et le Sed continue à dire librement vendeur, tandis que ce matin la reprise de 19 points leur fait dire "Price s'est racheté de crainte d'on Census Bureau bangsier." Mais ce qu'il y a de plus drôle, c'est que cette sortie momentanée du marché du leader de la baisse a été différemment appréciée, les uns l'ayant considérée comme un élément de faiblesse pour le marché par l'élimination d'une position qui, à 'coup sûr, était vi és par les haustiers, tandis que les autres, on envisageant ses mar livres fatales probable, mettaient les gens en garde contre une surprise à la hausse. De son côté, Prix, pour contenter tout le monde, fait câbler conseillant de se racheter pour le moment, à CADRO du prochain rapport d'Engrenage qui pourrait produire nne have provisoire, quitte à se dé. couvrir de nouveau quelques jours après, sur opinion étant toujours pour une baise graduelle et suivie. Et dire qu'il y aura des gens qui ne manqueront pas de lui faire son jeu !!

En régime, on n'est pas plus avancé aujourd'hui qu'il y a huit jonra et il n'y a plus, pour Me guider provisoirement, qu'à attendre le rapport du Census Bureau qui sera haus. sier, s'il confirme à peu près le chiffre que l'on attribue à la National Ginners A880 Ciation indiquant 186,000 Balles comme égrenoga de la dernière qoirzaine.

En attendant, ce qu'il y a de positif, s'est que les retraite de la filature en cotons Améri. cains sont toujours on domination sur l'année dernière et que ce n'est pas précisément là l'indice d'une augmentation de la consommation!
Poor revenir maintenant à notre marché, nous ajouterons que la nouvelle récolte & suivi plato lentement le mouvement de l'ancienne et qu'en tout et pour tout, Novembre a monté de 1/8.

Quant au disponible, il a été plutôt satisfaisant, quoique la grosse demande soit restés en quelque sorte limitée aux cotons fins, Good et au-dessus. Les provenances Hante-Egypte trouveraient amateurs, mais leur valeur actuelle trop élevée pour les classements supérieurs éloigne les acheteurs. Les cotons bas sont aussi chers pour cause de rareté. En somme, la semaine finit en haagse et, suivant la cote officielle de ce jour, cette hausse est de 3/8 sur toute la ligue.

La demas de continuer à être spécialement pour l'Angleterre, tandis que de la part de Continent et de l'Amérique elle s'est ralentie d'une façon très marquée. Cela ne doit pourtant pas nous étonner si nous considérons la situation exceptionnellement floribrante de Bolton et les approvisionnements déjà faits par les autres pays.

Les exportations ont été supérieures à tons les pronostics, talles 31,000, contre 21,000, et quoique pas dans les mêmes proportions, celles de la semaine prochaine promettent d'être fortes et de dépasser celles de la même période en 1905.
On prévoit un février plutôt faible, tandis que mars, à cause des engagements existants, mera probablement très important.
Liverpool a été assez actif pour nos cotons disponible, mais la cote en reste invariable. Sur les fattore, par contre, il y a un peu de hausse.

L'Américain aussi a donné lieu à plus d'af. faires en spot que cela n'ait été le cas pendant les deux ou trois semaines précédentes, mais sur ces cotons il y a une hausse proportionnée à celle de New York et de New Orléans.
Graines de Coton

La demande pour le disponible, par suite des besoins immédiats de quelques exportateurs qui se sont trouvés un peu pris au dépourvu, a été formidable et la conséquence a été tout simplement une bande de près de 41 Piastres pour la marchandise prête. Pour le livrable dans quelques jours on a même payé davantage.
Le fait est que les engagements pour le mois courant sont très gros et comme presque tous les vapeurs devant charger sont dans le port, la fin du resserrement actuel n'est pas encore près de finir.

L'Angleterre avait montré de la fermeté et avait suivi notre marché en payant jusqu'à £6. 8/9 pour Février et Mars, mais depuis quelques jours elle se montre récalcitrante et les dernières affaires n'ont pa obtenir que de £6 3/9 à £6 6/3, suivant position. C'est à la réaction de la graine de lin que serait dû le revirement constaté dans les dispositions de Hall et de Londres. Da reste, les expéditions qui ont eu lieu jusqu'ici offrent un grand approvisionnement à la consommation anglaise et il paraît avéré que sans l'impossibilité de se débarrasser de forêt engagé, plusieurs résiliations de marchés auraient été faites pour Hull. Londres, par contre, a pu annuler quel. ques affaires.

Les contrats ont été actifs et le Février Mars était monté jusqu'à P.T. 687, mais devant l'attitude de l'Étranger, quelques haussiers ont cru devoir liquider, ce qui a produit la réaction ja:qu'à P.T. 661. Seulement, comme au fond les huiles ont renchéri et comme la position de la graine de lin est toujours la même, l'avenir de l'article demeure favorable, à la spéculation reste un peu sage.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 19 janvier. Toutes nos prévisions de vendredi dernier se sont réalisées dans le courant même de la semaine : pour empêcher l'or d'émigrer, la Banque de France a été autorisée à porter l'émission de son papier de 5 milliarda å 5 milliards 800 millione; le taux privé d'escompte a bans-é en Angleterre de 3 5/8 à 3 7/8 et les nouvelles politiques elles-mêmes se sont notablement améliorées aussi bien en Rossie qu'au Maroc; ce ne sont de tous côtés que paroles de conciliation, qu'il s'agisse de Guillaume, d'Edouard VII, de Visconti-Venosta ou de Bolow. Le mieux eat cependant d'attendre les événements, et c'est ce que fait le monde de la spéculation, avec une unanimité vraiment exemplaire.

Il n'y a pas, en effet, de crise monétaire proprement dite. L'argent abonde, particulièrement en France. En Angleterre même on fait couratoment da report A 3 1/2 poar cent, et 5 %, s'il s'agit de reports libres. Il est vrai qa'd New-York le prix de l'argent est encore fantastique, cent pour cent, mais l'Amérique n'est-elle pas le pays des merveilles ? Un fait est certain, c'est que les disponibilités sont loin de faire défaut en Europe et qu'à port le grain d'Algésiras le marché financier se présente sous le meilleur aspect pour l'année 1906. A peine ca nuage aura-t-il dieparu que les coura rattraperont le temps perdo. | loi notre bourse suit pas à pas les flootuations de Londres et de Paris, mais on s'abstenant généralement de conclure de nouvelles affaires importantes. Elle reste sagement dans l'expectative.

Anssi la semaine n'a-t-elle pas été remarquable au point de vue des transactions. Samedi elle ouvre calme ; seuls l'Urbaine, la Salt and Soda, los Upper Egypt Hotels, la Cassa di Sconto montrent un peu d'animation. Suivent deox jours de repo3 à l'occasion du premier de l'an greo. Mardi l'ouvertaro a liga en baisse et la clotore aussi, en dépit d'ane reprise vers opz, heares ; log transactions sont restreintes. Mais le lendemain, après un magvais début, la cote 80 raffermit et clôtare en hausse partielle. Hier, nouveau début dans le marasme, pour reprendre dans la saite, en particulier sor les Banqres; le journée finit forme et relativement animée. Aujourd'hui enfiu, on a été sontenu, gartout en Nangovich, Nationale et Agricole, mais les affaires demenrent clairsemée. On peut dono résumer la semaine dans ces deux mots : transactions rares et soutien relatif.

Ce sont les banques qui foornissent à elles seules presque tout l'appoint de la hs08ee : la Nationale, l'Agricole, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Cassa di Sconto. La Nationale gøgne 5/16 sar la semaine passée. Parmi les autres valears en balese il faut signaler l'Urbaine qui monte de 1/8, la Béhéra, la Filatore, les Cotton Mille, la Salt & Soda et la Nangovich. Tout le reste de la cota est stationnaire on en baisse plus ou moins sensible : il y & par exemple, la Delta Light Deferred qui perd la bagatelle d'une livre sterling.

A ce propos, c'est le 30 courant que doit se réanir à Londres l'assemblée des actionnaires de la Delta Light Le conseil d'administration proposera, parait-il, à cette assemblée, la digtribation d'une dividende de 2 %, ce qai, avec le dividende provisoire de % qui a été distribué en jain dernier, fera un dividende global de 4 % pour l'exercice.

On sait que la Cassa di Sconto porte son capital de cinq à dix millions de franca, par l'émission de 50,000 actions nouvelles de 100 franca. 30.000 de ces actions ont déjà été prises par l'Union Bank de Vienne au prix de 135 francs ; les 20.000 qui restent sont offertes &nx anciens actionnaires au prix de 130 franos, dans la proportion de 2 actions nouvelles pour 5 anciennes. LS souscription sera ouverte da 29 courant au 6 tévrier.

La rapport des Cotton Mille qui sera présenté à l'assemblée des actionnaires do 25 conrant à Londres vignt d'être publié. Il signale un profit de £14,409 contre £992 l'année dernière. Ce résultat inattenda produit un excellent effet sur la place; déjà la valeur commence à donner des signes de relèvement.

Après la perte du procès en préemption du Mena House qa'on leur avait intentée, les Nangovich avaient reoulé jusqu'à 11 5/8. . Ils viennent de remonter à 11 3/4 à la suite de l'achat d'an emplacement à coté du Mena, en vue d'y construire un hotel concurrent au cas où ils perdraient encore en appel.

L'Urbaine continue à défrayer les conversations dans les petits comités de la Bourse. La Société, dit on, aurait rompa les pourparlers de fusion avec les Buildings Lands pour en entomer d'antres avec la société plas cos8de des Immeubles, qui possède ape grande partie des maisons de la Rue Chérif. Da coup les Building ont perda l'avance qu'ils avaient gagné ces jours derniers. On dit encore an Bojet de l'Urbaine qu'en outre da beau dividende qu'elle va distribuer, elle porters sept à huit mille livres à la réserve. Un autre succès qui n'est pas à dédaigner pour cette société c'est son gain da procès en préemption qu'on loi avait intenté sur les terrains de la Compagnie da Gaz et coux adjacenta. Comme elle a acheté con terrains 4 livres le pic at qu'on les paie 8 anjourd'hui, c'est en définitive un bénéfice de 30.000 livres que les préempteurs n'ont pas réussi à lui enlever.
Voilà à peu près tout ce qu'il y a d'intéres sant à dire pour cette semaine.

Notre conclusion de vendredi passé reste valable pour la semaine qoiva suivre. La situation politique et monétaire n'a guère changé depnis, et les probabilités sont toojours pour l'heurense i8nne des conflits existants, mais, comme il faut faire la part de l'impréva, il est bon de se tenir ear la réserve et de n'opérer qu'aveo prudence sur les valeurs qui obéissent trop fiddlement aux fluctoations des marchés egropéens, pour le rejeter momentanément sur les valeurs égyptient es foncières et immobilières qui présentent de sérieuses garanties et qui sont par le fait à l'abri de tonte surprise. Ces mozares de prodende une fois gardéag, nous croyons pouvoir sfirmer que la capitaliste égyptien ne court aucon risqše. Bientôt la période de hausse annuelleva commencer et l'incertitude politique ne pourra pas l'empêcher de enivre son coora ; tont an plus pourra-t-elle en retarder l'essor de quelques semaines.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA
div.p: L'AIGLON La première représentation de cette pièce donnée hier soir a été un véritable événement artistique pour notre ville. Le public très nombreux, qui y as-instruit, a suivi avec une religieuse attention la marche du drame.

Il n'y a pas précisément de thèse dans la pièce ; mais c'est une peinture tout à fait vivante da duc de Reichstadt, fils de Napoléon ler. L'auteur a voulu le faire revivre sous nos geox et il y a pleinement réussi. Les difficultés auxquelles le Prince était en batte, l'ambition d'imiter son père jusque dans les moindre: détails psychologiques, tout y a été traité de main de maître.

Ajoutez à cela un style facile et brillant, un dialogue plein de verve, anvers simple et coulant et vous aurez le qualités essentielle da chef-d'œuvre de Rostand, qualité, qui loi ont 898 créé dans toute l'Europe la vigne que l'on sait.

L'interprétation a été au-degas de tout éloge. Il faut citer en particulier Mme Moreno qui a déployé toute la mesure de son talent dans ce rôle superbe, mais écrasant du Duc de Reichstadt. Eile & on les bonngora de ls soirée par la sincérité de son jeu et la chaleur de ses accents. L98 rôles de femmes ont été fort bien tends par Mme Patry dans le personnage de Marie Louise, Mme Franquet dans celui de Camerata, ainsi que Mme: Gauraz et Beylat dang conx de Thérèse et de l'Archiduchesse. M. Daragon & fort bien compris le rôle de Flamboyan, an chevalier de la garde, qui a en boskoop de Baobės. M. Montgueux a été un Metternich parfait,
Le publio a sbagliate par des a'padi889 ments nourri: 183 tirados patrick 101 qui abondent dans la pièce et qui ont été simirabloment dites par les artistes.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Awjm Urd'hui à midi st domis) On & ouvert calme ce matin. Pen pen, Dépendant, la Corbeille s'est animée et 'est en pleine effervescence qu'elle a clôturé.

L'attention s'est portée particulièrement sur les Statuts, les Nangovich et les Banques, mais plusieurs autres valeurs ont participé à ce mouvement, entre autres le Comptoir, la New Egyptian et l'Urbaine.
Les Patates gagnent 1/32 à 1 21/32, la Nao Govich 3/16 à 12, la New Egyptian 6 penco à 28/9, la Salt and 80:18 9 pence à 20/9.

L'Urbaine est demandée à 5 5/16.
En revanche la Banque Nationale fléchit légèrement à 25 %, le Crédit Foncier à 802, at 11 Dira à 17 7/16. .

Les Sucreries tombent à 21, la Khedivial Email à 4 tot l'Alexandria Water & 14. Sur ces dernières valeurs la perte est relativement importante: elle est respectivement de 3 franos et . . - Caire, 19 janvier. Les cours ont été plus fermes bier à Londres. Le Consolidé anglais & clôturé avec de haagse à 90 ; l'Unifie avec un à 104 5. La National Bank & également gagné 1 à 25 1. Par contre, la Daïra a perdu $ à 175 L'Agricole est rester inchangée à 9 1/2.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier & clôturé comme la veille, à 805.
Notre marché des valente a été, co matin, calme, mais forme.
La National Banks ootaré à 25 acheteurs; - l'Agricole à 9 9/16, demandée également.
L'action Crédit Foncier ne maintient à 803. Les obligations à lots 1886 restent à 333 et 'la nouvelle émission à 274..
L'action Enterprise and Development a avancé à 12 et la part de fondateur d 9.
L'action Boario Khédiviale du Caire aut remontée à £160.
Les Ciments d'Egypte se sont inscrits : 69
Dans le groupe des hôtels, les Nongovict ont avancé à 11 13/16. Los Baebler ont été
obtenus à 3 et les National & 4 - Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian nt clôturé à 28 sb. 3 après avoir tait 27 sh. 6. Les Investments Abdy ont été traités à 1 3/32.

L'Assemblée générale ordinaire des porteurs le parts de la Société civile de la Bourse Khé. liviale da Caire a été tenne bier, à 6 b. p.m., laps le local de la Bourse,8008 la présidence de le M. Maurice Cattaci bey.
Le rapport du Comité exposant l'état prospère de la Société, et le rapport des consoeurs ont été approuvés à l'unanimité.
On a procédé cassette à l'élection de deux membres du Comité en remplacement de deux membres sortants; M. M. Paul Oziol et A. Cattani ont été réélus.
M. Williamson & été élu membre du conseil en remplacement de M. McGillivray. M. Salinas . été nommé censeur,

Pais, à la soite d'ane longue discussion, l'as. emblée & adopté une motion donnant au Comité mandat de traiter avec la Corporation les agents de change pour l'achat du terrain par lequel sera construite la nouvelle Bourse.
Da annoncs d'Alexandria que l'Egyptian Estates Company vient d'acheter la vaste propriété de M. Amabile Cumbo à Atfah, sor les orda do canal Mahmoudieh.
La Société aurait fait cette acquisition à des conditions très avantageuses.

Les actionnaires de l'Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. sont informés que le délai fixé Par les Statuts pour le 3ème versement de L'I expire le 1er février prochain. Les Forcements en retard seront passibles d'un intérêt de 7%
Hacene sur les cotons en Amérique. Le Disponible a gagné bier 15 points; le Mai 19 et l'Octobre 9.
Les arrivages ont été, de 14,000 balles contre 16,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est également en reprise sensible.
loi, le Mars a ouvert, oo matin, á 16 3/16 pour clôturer à 16 1/4.

div.head: OUR LONDON LETTER:
div.p: (PHOM QUR CORRESPONDENT).

Loudun, January 12. Today the General Election açtaally began with the premature contest at Ipswich, which seeme peculiarly appropriate to the ciroom stal ces of the party for the moment in power. To get a majority over the Unionista, even with the aid of the Nationalists the Radicals mas, as the "Times" points out this morning, win thirty-foor seats. To get a bare majority over Unionists and Nationalists they must win one hundred and seventeen, and to obtain & majority which will give them a Government with even as moch Parliamentary support as that of the last Radical Administration, they must capture one bundred and thirty-seven Beatnow held by Unionists. The contempla. tion of these figures may serve to restore those Unio: ists who still view with apprehension the isane of the conflict, and should serve to send them into the battle wi:b big and confident hopes.

As the polls draw nearer, the annoyance of the Radical party chile grows against the Labour ma wbo are going to carry their scorn of the Great Liberal Party to the extent of queering its pitch and letting in the less "invidious" Tory. At Huddersfield the other night Mr. Asquith was quite pathetic over it, and, last night, at Middlesbrough, Mr. Lloyd George was really cross about this Labour ''cantankerousness." He was supporting Mr. Havelook Wilson, the sailors' "Iriond,'' against pot only a Unionist but also a thorough-faced I.L.P. man. Oily joey before that, Mr. Lloyd George sadly set forth, be bad being a full blown Labour man at Darlington ; and we may add that before that he had been supporting a Radical at Croydon in circumstances painfully like those of Middlesbrough. It is a case for genuine ommigeration, this matter inability of the Radicals to discover where they are with the Labour men, in spite of all their attempts to catch the Labour vote, and even the "con. pliment to Battersea." They will have moral enlightenment on the point on Saturday night at Bradford, for instance..

In their anxiety to defeat Mr. Balfour, the Manchester Liberals have achieved a record in grotesque reasoning, as well as in a much less amiable direction. The electors are invited to reject Mr. Balfour because an op flattering reference to bit grandfather as a Daval contractor has been found in the papers of a gentleman who died in 1842. Prom & party which bcing the hereditary principle this inquisition of pedigree is rather more than we were prepared for ; the rest of the handbill in which it appears is more characteristic of the Radical temperament, though more than usual. ly infamous in its sourrility. It rang as follows:
Dues Breed Tell? If it doer, every votes given to a Conservativa is & vote given

to the Imperial Thieves' Kitchen. This gen of "righteous e39" may be allowed to sparkle, unconfined by any setting of com meat. The office! Liberals of Mun haster will probably announce that they are not responsible for the circulation of the band bill or for its competition. They will hardly suggest however, that it was written and fent to the printer's by a Unionisti

It will be interesting to know whether Si Charles Dilka's election address is the shortest on record. Omi tiog the "Gentlemen '' and "Believe me, &..," it consists of exactly nice words. So far as we know this cor atitates record in one direction, just as, we believe Sir Henry Campbell-Bannermsa's address does in the other. If, as we may assume is tolerably certaio, Sir Charles Dilke is ro-elected, bo wil enter Parliament with the freest hand o anyone there, for his address does not contain A single pledge of any description, and b might, if he so pleased, steadily vote against the present Government without his consti twenty having any ground for complain'.

The sudden death of Lord Ritchie while the first General Election of a fiscal kind is in it very throo is a cori 18 parallel to the demise of Mr. Forstor during the Home Rule crisis The news moet have been received with tb greatest regret alike by the old colleagues and Supporters of the late statesman, and by bi now Piea Trade assc ciater, for the strength 8n Minority of big convictions were com o knowledge, and in breaking bi- political career for the sake of an economic principle, he made a sacrifice which never goes without bonoa Mr. Ritchie's record in the Con ervative part was a curiously chequered one. He was no cut out for popularity, and his opinions leare in a direction not remote from R.dicalium, that some of his treasures provoked considerable restiveness on the benches behind him. By a combination of ability, industry, and character, however, he reached high office, and it was only the emergence of the Fiscal question, with its hyper-theological animosities, that made a definite broach in his party associations. Lord Ritchie's repeal of the orn daty, together with his creation of County Councils, will secure his place in the pages of the political analyst.

Although we are enjoying a winter almost too mild for the majority of people, there are not wanting signs that we shall have cold weather later on. A correspondent of a sporting contemporary mentions that while on the south coast a few days ago he saw a pair of golden-oye docks. He adds : "I had not seen golden-eye on this particular part of the coast since the tremendous frost of January, 1895." This takes to be a sign that a spell of severe weather is imminent, as thoga birds are almost unknown so far south. It is a most remarkable thing that birds, and, in fact, most animals, seem to have the power of foreseeing the weather weeks ahead. Seagulls, for instance, invariably ny inland before a gala rises, 80 that they may not be blown out to sea; while ornithologists are still in the dark as to the migratory habits of some birds.

The evidence given at the inquest on the victims of the Charing cross disaster showed quite clearly that it was impossible to guard against it, and that no blame was attached to anyone. The experts are all agreed that the accident was due to the fracture of one of the tio-bars, due to an invisible flaw, which in all probability was present in the bar when it was originally put in its place. Such flowers oscar from time to time in both iron and steel, and as yet science gives no means of detecting tbem. The defective bar would be to all outward seeming perfectly bound, bat it con. taided a flaw which, according to Sir Benjamin Baker's evidence, reduced its strength to 000third of what it was intended to be. With the alternations of heat and cold the bar expanded and contracted. The natural reaalt was that the original flaw grew larger and larger under the varying strain, until at last the tie-bar gave way altogether, and the roof came down.

Sir Elwin Cornwall, its spoms, has been forestalled. His proposal for an international exchange of school children - 80 the "Morning Post's" Paris correspondent informs 08-bas been anticipated by private initiative. Two years ago a society was started in Paris by a gentleman who wished to afford others the advantage he himself badly reaped by sending his own children abroad and receiving little foreigners into his own home. Up to the present most business has been done with Ger. many, which realises more keenly than Eog. land the advantage of sending its children to France. Oar lack of perception is attributed to conservatism. We are inclined to think that most English parents will remain blind to the blessings of the scheme. They cannot, of course, deny that a boy or girl learns & language better by living where it is naturally spoken. They may well approve a system under which children not of tender years would spend limited periods as inmates of Pronoh families. But they must be prepared to guard against the disadvantages of the scheme. What the child would gain in knowledge it might lose, without proper safeguards, in education. For true education means the building of character, and a good English character, we are conservative enough to believe, is best formed amid Baglish Bor roundings.

It is pleasing to see as an "a musical nation" to hear of the triumph of the Leede Choir ia Paris. There can be no doubt that they made a deep impression on their French audience. The tumult of applause at the conclusion of their performance might have beer attributed to the generosity of friends and boats. No such explanation can be given of the sensation caused by the wonderful singing of Parisian critics and musicians. From their tributes we are bound to conclude the
the Yorkshire choir have introduced a dove L'artiste pleasure to the finer goals of th
French capital. "The Standard" corresponden describes the rendering of Bach's Motet as " feat of combination, of sustained freedom, and
of deft and balanced expression, particularlY in the slow movement, which really startle
those who did not know the meaning of choral singing, and surprised even those who often heard the Leeds Choir before." Bye
London hardiy realises what Yorkshire--ar I wa may add Weleh-choirs can accomplish
and if their own metropolis is ignorant , what wonder that Paris should have been taken by storm!

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Next month Colonel P. 8. Marling, V. C., will vacate the command of the 18th (Princess of Wales's) Hassara at York. The command, it is understood, will go to Major W. P. M. Pollok-Morris, the second in command, and the majority should go to Captain C. H. LAVeson, who is now employed with the Khedive's army.

The vacant company in the Royal Fusiliers has gone to Lieutenant H. O. Forster, of the 1st Battalion at Parkhurst. Captain Forster ge's his company after just seven years' service, having been appointed to his first commission in January 1899. He served with the 3rd Battalion in Egypt in 1901-02.

Ligatenant R. G. B. Jeffreys, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, who recently took up the adjatancy of the 1st Battalion in Egypt, has been promoted captain. Captain Jeffreys served nearly eight years for this third atar. As already noted here, he served in the South African Campaign.

The 1 t Battalion of the Royal West Kents at Malta base just got a new adjutant in the person of Captain H. W. Soow, in 8000assion to Captain J. W. O'Dowda, whose term bad expired. Captain Snow has served for some given years in the regiment and has commanded a company for the past fifteen months.

The 3rd Battalion Royal Fusiliers, which was stationed in Egypt a few years ago, and from there went to Bermuda, has arrived at Middelburg, Cape Colony, from the latter place, on change of station. This battalion was one of the fourteen added to the army in recent soiree. It was to be reduced, but, like other of Arnold Porator's Echomes, it will not be carried out.

The re-arming of the battalions of the Foot Guards with the new short rifle began to-day. As soon as that is completed the rearmament of the first six infantry brigades will be proceeded with. It is pretty certain that a full' armament of the entire army will not be carried out pending the experiments with the automatic rifle on the Continent and in the States,

It is not often that Lord Kitchener permits himself to be interviewed, but it is doubtless owing to the misunderstanding as to his position which the recent dispute bag change that has induced him to talk freely to Dr. W. H. Fitohet, who gives a coolant of the conver. station in the "Daily Mail." Lord Kitchener, of course, denies the absurd suggestion of a military autocracy, and freely admits that the civil power is, and most be, saprome. All that Lord Kitohener has contended for in this connection is the right to pat "adequately and personally my own plads before the Government (the ladis Government] to which I am responsible." Under the old system there was that worst of all military falta, a division of authority. 'I gavo ono set of instructions to a General upon a certain subject, and the military member of the coupoil gave another set of instructions to the same General on the same subject.``

This week the oraiser Kent, Captain 8. V. Y. De Horsey, is going through her steam trials on completing to seagoing strength. On conclusion of her trials, if all passes off satisfactorily, she will leave Sheerness for the China Station, where, as already intimated in these boats, she will relieve the croiser Hogno, Captain R G. Shortland. The Kent is probably the slowest of her type, having been accepted as a 22}-koot ship, bat lat. terly better speed has been gotten out of her. One of the most remarkable things in abip. building is the discrepancy of speed in ships built, on exactly the same lines, bolt for bolt.

After a service of forty years the St. Vincent, training ship for young seamen at Portsmouth, is to pay off in the course of the next few days. Her paying-off pendant, which was hoisted on Thursday, ia 270 ft. long. The boys have been transferred to their new quarters at Shirley, Harwich, where excellent shore barracks have been erected. The St. Vincent was laid down at Plymouth dockyard in the year after Trafalgar, and was launched in 1915, in the presence of 50,000 spectators. She was a vessel of 120 gade, and was sister ship to the Nelson and to the Howe, the three being named after the great Admirals. For a long time she did flagship daty at Portsmouth, and in the "forties", with the Channel and Mediterranean Fleets On one occasion she ran into the Point Beach, Portsmouth, and her bowsprit went through the window of a hotel.

The time honoured institution of the boatswain's pipe which has fallen into considerable digose in these modern days of bogle calle, appears lately to have been found so obegal BA to justify its resuscitation in the Navy. The Admiralty has therefore approved the supply of a certain number of pipes to enable systematic instruction in their ose to be given to petty officers and boys. Ability to "pipe" has been included in examination at the depot at Portsmouth, also in the Mediterranean Fleet Twelve pipes of different compositions and different bores are to be supplied to the Bomoath, the flagship of the Channel Fleet, for trial and report as to which type of pipe is considered suitable for any in His Majesty's whips.

div.head: THE HORSE AND HIS RIDER.
div.p: One of the most interesting articles in this month's "Nineteenth Century" is that by Mr Wilfred Scawan Blunt on the genealogy of the tborongbbred horse, in the coorbe of which be incidentally raises the question : when was the horse first ridden by man? The geological record shows him to have been haunted in Borope ky prehistoric man in the late Stone Age, but there is no indication of even an approximate date at which he may have become domesticated. His earliest appearance in the civilised world at the dawn of history shows him contrary to what we should Datorally export, as being used for draught and not for riding. There is no record of his having been mounted in any country much before 1000 BC., although the ancient Arcadian Kings are said to have possessed chariots two thousand years earlier. Only in North-Western Africa is there any indication that the bcr-e was first ridden rather than driveo. Mr. Blunt's theory of the reason why the borsa in early ci j'igation was only used for draught is that he was first tamel in the northern plains, or cold regions of Upper Asia or Eastern Borope, wbori snow lay long in winter, and so may have suggested the use of animals for drawing sledzis rather than for riding. Probably the first wild animal to be tamed by man was the dog. The reindeer may have followed the dog. and at a later date, bat still as a draught animal, came the horse. The art of taming and breeding animals thus acquired in their first northern homes would have been carried with them by the Mongols and Aryans in their migrations southwards inta lands where snow was unknown, and where the soligo, no longer of use, came to be replaced by more suitable wheeled vehicles. The idea of mounting and riding the horse, then only a ball broken, mast that has come to man in the southern plains, and at a later date.

div.head: 34 YEARS OF RHEUMATISM.
div.p: Patient laid up in Bed for 10 Month at a time, Disablod and Helpless.
4, York street,

Bilstop, Staffs., England. Gentlemen :- I will always do what I can towards making your Doan's Backache Kidney Pillow better known, because they have proved such a blessing to me, and I beliveo in them. I have been a martyr to rheumatism ever since I was 20 years of age, and now I am 64. When I was quite a young man I had to walk with crutches or stickers. This went on for over three years, and since that time I have never been properly free from the rheumatism, but never bo free as I am at the present time, since asing Doan's Pills

During those 31 years I had several severe attacks of this terrible rheumatism. The one in October of 1897, when I was living in Wednesbury, was, I think, the severest attack I ever had; it kept me in my bed for 10 months, and I became as helpless as a new-born babe. I was attended by one of the best doctors, but he seemed unable to do much good, although he told me more than once that if I had been a millionaire he could not have tried harder--and I believe him.

In March of 1899 I was kept from business for 17 months again with rheumatism and kidney trouble. There were severe pains in my back and sides (especially the left side); my appetite became poor, and I didn't relish the food I was able to eat. There was a nasty taste in my mouth, no matter what I ate or drank, and I couldn't keep my focd down. Even a pipa of tobacco seemed to go against me, and I became despondent and miserable, feeling that life was not worth living.

Bat there was worse to follow : not long after, I began to be troubled with the kidney secretions, the pain in passing being almost unbearable at times. There was alcohol & Bodiment from the gripe. These distressing complaints kopt getting worse and worse as months went by, antil one day I couldn't pass the urine at all; I was in such a terrible condition at the time that I thought my race was nearly over.
ron.

It was then that I heard about Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and they were spoken 80% highly . I was determined to try them. After I had taken a few boxes I telt easier, and now that I have taken ten boxes I feel quita free from any sign of rheumatism or kidney trouble. I am a new man to what I was, thanks to your Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. They are indeed worth their weight in gold.
Hoping you will excuse this long letter, and again thanking you for my new health and strength, I remain,
Yours very gratefully,

(Signed) CHARLES OSBORNE. Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 18 P.T. par box, on 71 P.T. for 6 boxes; or they may be had direot from the general agent for Egypt, - Max Pinchor, Monaky Stroot, Cairo.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
